In that activity Ni Ketut Kasiani opens her business from 07:30 AM and closes at 22:00 at night. From the capital used so far are about Rp3000,000 (about US$ 330), Ni Ketut Kasiani daily sales are about Rp100,000 (about US$11), and nett profit of about Rp25,000 (about US$2.75). That income is not sufficient to pay for daily family expenses, which increases daily. With an additional capital from Dinari for about Rp4,000,000 (about US$440) Ni Ketut Kasiani could increase the selection of sales item, with the hope it would increase sales and nett profit from her business.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Ni Ketut Kasiani merupakan potret seorang ibu sekaligus istri yang luar biasa. Dalam keseharian hidupnya ia mampu membantu suami dalam menambah penghasilan keluarga melalui usaha menjual pulsa dan aksesoris telepon genggam yang berada di depan rumahnya . Dalam kegiatanya Ni Ketut Kasiantini mulai membuka usahanya pukul 7.30 pagi dan akan tutup pada pukul 22.00 malam. Dari semua modal yang dipergunakan selama ini yang berjumlah Rp. 3.000.000,- Ni Ketut Kasiantini mendapatkan hasil penjualan selama satu hari sebesar Rp.100.000.- dengan keuntungan bersih sekitar Rp .25 000,- Dari penghasilan sebesari tu, belumlah cukup untuk memenuhi kebutuhan keluarganya yang semakin hari semakin meningkat. Dengan tambahan modal dari DINARI sebesar Rp. 4.000.000,- Ni Ketut Kasiani bisa menambah jumlah jenis barang yang akan dijual kepada pembeli dengan harapan bisa meningkatkan hasil penjualan dan dan juga keuntungan bersih dari hasil usahanya.

loans.use:
To add capital and increase sales

Menambah modal untuk memperbanyak dagangannya

loans.name: Estela

texts.es:
Estela is 28 years old, married, and has one daughter who is 10 years old and at primary school.

She has had a small business for several years. It's a small liquor store where she sells different types of drinks. Her business is located in the city center of Mariano Roque Alonso and the name of the business refers to an international route which is called Transchaco.

Because she is in an active busy area, she has very good sales and her customers are usually travelers and residents of neighboring regions

She seeks a loan to invest in her business. She would like to buy different types of drinks like sodas, beers, wines, whiskeys, hard ciders and others since this time of the year, sales increase considerably.

Translated from Spanish by Geraldine Kim, Kiva Translator.

La Sra. Estela tiene 28 años, esta en pareja y tiene una hija de 10 años que esta cursando la primaria de la educación básica. Posee una microempresa desde hace varios años, es una bodega donde se dedica a la venta de diferentes tipos de bebidas, esta ubicada en el centro de la ciudad de Mariano Roque Alonso, y el nombre del negocio es por que se encuentra sobre una Ruta Internacional que se llama Transchaco.

Debido a que se encuentra en una zona de mucho movimiento tiene muy buenas ventas, sus clientes generalmente son viajeros y vecinos de la zona.

Solicita el crédito para poder invertirlo en la compra de diferentes tipos de bebidas como gaseosas, cervezas, vinos, whiskys, sidras, entre otros ya que en esta época del año aumenta considerablemente las ventas.

loans.use: compra de diferentes tipos de bebidas como gaseosas, cervezas, vinos, whiskys, sidras, etc.

loans.name: Chin

texts.en: Mrs. Chin S., age 37, is a widow and works as a traditional doctor making around $4 each day in revenue. She has two children, one who is a fisherman making $4 each day, and the other is a student. She would like to request a loan of $1000 in order to open a grocery stand to enable her to generate additional profits for her family.

loans.use: To open a grocery stand to enable her to generate additional profits for her family.

loans.name: Angelina

texts.es:
In January 1996 Angelina started selling cosmetics, perfumes and household products. A friend invited her to a perfume testing at her home, and that’s what she started selling first. As the business prospered, in 2000 she incorporated cosmetics of renowned brands, as well as naturistic products. To date, she has been able to maintain the business, with lows and highs. The income has allowed her to pay for the education of her three children, who she wishes to eventually send to college.

Angelina wishes to buy more merchandise in order to offer new products to her clients. For this reason she is requesting a $850 loan, that she is willing to repay in five months. With your help Angelina and her family will make it.

Translated from Spanish by Leticia Britos, Kiva Volunteer.

En enero de 1996, Angelina comenzó a vender cosméticos, perfumes y artículos para el hogar, gracias a una amiga que la invitó a su casa a una demostración de perfumes, y esto fue lo primero que empezó a vender. Como le empezó a ir bien, en el año 2000 incorporó también cosméticos de reconocidas marcas, además de productos naturistas. Hasta la fecha ha mantenido este negocio con altas y bajas. Sin embargo el dinero que gana le sirve para poder pagar los estudios de sus tres hijos, a quienes desea brindarles la oportunidad de estudiar una carrera universitaria.

Angelina desea comprar más mercancía para poder ofrecer nuevos productos a sus clientes. Es por eso que está solicitando un crédito de US$ 850 que está dispuesta a pagar en un plazo de 5 meses. Con tu ayuda Angelina y su familia podrán salir adelante.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise.

loans.name: Ashura's Mzinga Group

texts.en:
Ashura A., age 42, is a single parent with three children aged 13, 18 and 22. She started a small street cafe six years ago, and began selling clothing and sarongs last year. At these businesses, she works daily from 7:30 a.m. to 2 p.m., making a profit of about $235 a month from food and clothing sales.

In the past, Ashura took two loans from Tujijenge Tanzania and used them to buy food to sell and start her sarong business. Having paid these loans back successfully, she hopes for a new loan to buy more food, clothing and sarongs to sell. She will share this loan with her group Mzinga, which totals 15 members.

In the picture, Ashura is standing in the back row, second from the left.

loans.use: To buy food, sarongs and other items that will be sold by several small businesses.

loans.name: Victory Self-Help Group

texts.en:
Miriam M. is a middle-aged Kenyan widow and a mother to two children. She also lives with two orphaned children, whom she must feed, clothe, and educate.

Miriam’s primary business is fish vending, which started four years ago. She got her initial capital from an informal rotating savings fund (commonly referred to as "merry go round") that her group had. She mainly concentrates on selling tilapia, but occasionally sells omena (small fish), which she says boosts her profit margin. Miriam mostly sells her fish on a retail basis to her regular customers. With her loan, however, she will be able to buy more tilapia to increase her sales and eventually expand to wholesale.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: Expansion of fish business

loans.name: Gwantwa

texts.en:
Mambo (Hello!) from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 39 year-old Gwantwa M.. She is single and has two children, ages 12 and 17, plus two other dependents,

In 2005, Gwantwa established her fish business. Gwantwa needs a loan to buy addiitonal stocks of a small local fish called a "dagaa," which is similar to an anchovy. It is dried, sold in cans, and is traditionally added to soups and stews. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility, as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of dagaa fish in bulk.

loans.name: Oimgul

texts.ru:
Oimgul B. is a resident of Khuroson distrct. She’s married and has two children. She has a higher education and works as a teacher in a secondary school. To supplement her income, she runs a small stall near her home where she sells food products. She has been doing this for three years now and would like to expand her stall and stock turnover. To do so, she decided to take out a loan that she expects to repay within 10 months. This will enable her to increase her business and income which she needs to support her family.

Translated from Russian by Josh Machleder, Kiva Volunteer.

Бобоева Оимгуль жительница района Хуросон. Замужем мать двоих детей. Имеет высшее образование. Работает учителем в средней школе. Кроме того подрабатывает торговлей. Имеет небольшую торговую точку рядом с домом , где продает продукты питания. Занимается этим делом уже три года. Теперь хочет увеличить торговую точку и товарооборот. Для этого она решила получить кредит со сроком на 10 месяцев. Это поможет увеличить бизнес и увеличить доход , необходимый для ее семьи.

loans.use: Increase of stock

loans.name: Tiéssiri (Courage) Group

texts.fr:
The nine members of the Tiéssiri Group are all married and average 32 years of age and three children. They generally live in polygamous households with their husbands, co-spouses, and children in the Sokala district of Zambougou Fouta , Ségou Prefecture (Republic of Mali). This group of women, who are linked by ties of community, age, and clan, does trading in agricultural products and other goods of small-scale commerce. In order to meet the stronger and stronger demand, this group decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program, which just allocated the members their first loan.

They resupply their inventory locally in Zambougou and in surrounding villages (Teisserela et Ganssola) from pilot growers for agricultural products. The supply of the various goods is gotten from Ségou from wholesalers of the grand marketplace. These women each have storage space on the allotted family plots for keeping their inventory. They each intend to use this loan to buy: one sack of beans, a sack and a half of rice, 15 sacks of millet, and 250 liters of milk.

Sales are made at the retail level, cash and credit accepted, from home most of the time and at the public square and in the marketplaces of nearby villages. The customers are generally made up of city inhabitants and of specialists in the stocking up and selling of agricultural products. The projected profits are estimated at 8,000 francs CFA and will serve to cover the loan interest and to bolster working capital.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Les neuf (9) femmes du groupe Tiéssiri sont toutes mariées et ont une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans, 3 enfants. Elles vivent généralement dans des foyers polygamiques avec leurs maris, coépouses et enfants dans le quartier Sokala de Zambougou Fouta préfecture de Ségou (République du Mali). Ce groupe de femmes lié par des relations de voisinage de groupe d’âge et de parenté, exerce le commerce de produits agricoles et d’autres articles de petit commerce. Afin de satisfaire la demande de plus en plus forte, ce groupe a décidé d’intégrer le programme de crédit de Soro Yiriwaso qui vient de leur octroyer leur premier prêt.

Elles se ravitaillent sur place à Zambougou et dans les villages environnants (Teisserela et Ganssola,) auprès de paysans pilotes pour les produits agricoles. Pour les articles divers l’approvisionnement se fait à partir de Ségou auprès des grossistes du grand marché. Ces femmes disposent toutes d’un lieu de stockage au niveau de la concession familiale pour la garde des produits avant la vente. Elles comptent acheter chacune avec ce prêt, 1 sac de haricot, 1 sac et 1 /2 de riz, 15 sacs de petit mil ; 250 litres de lait.

La vente se fait en détail au comptant et à crédit à domicile la plupart du temps et sur la place publique et dans les foires de villages non éloignés. La clientèle est généralement constituée de citadins et des spécialises du stockage et vente des produits agricoles. Les bénéfices prévisionnels estimés à 8 000 FCFA. serviront à payer les intérêts du prêt et renforcer le fonds de commerce.

loans.use: To buy grains and fresh cow's milk

loans.name: Claudia Maria

texts.es:
A sus 67 años, Claudia es socia del Banco Comunal “Las Candelarias II”D. Huaraz, ha sabido hacer crecer su negocio D. restaurante, ella nos cuenta que en un momento estuvo a punto D. dejar este negocio porque no vendía lo suficiente por estar en un lugar alejado D. la ciudad y aparentemente escondido, y sufrir la enfermedad D. su esposo con quien tiene ocho hijos.
Hace cinco años ella renació D. entre las cenizas, después D. las dificultades le llegó la hora D. crecer y ahora “La Rinconada”es uno D. los recreos mas visitados en la zona D. Huaraz y también uno D. los mas alquilados cada fin D. semana para realizar todo tipo D. eventos, ahora junto a su esposo y dos D. sus hijos, ella prepara los alimentos. 

Con el préstamo D. S/800 soles, que pagará en 6 cuotas, ella comprará 2 % D. sillas plásticas para su restaurante “La Rinconada” que se encuentra en el Jr. Huaylas, del distrito D. independencia D. la ciudad D. Huaraz,  porque las que tiene ya no son suficientes.
texts.en:
At age 67, Claudia is a partner of Banco Comunal "Las Candelarias II" from Huaraz. She has managed to help her restaurant business grow. She tells us that at one point she considered giving up because sales were not enough -- the restaurant was too far from the city and it was hard to find. To make matters worse, her husband, with whom she has eight children, fell ill. It has been five years now since she brought herself out of a very difficult situation and turned "La Rinconada" into one the most visited places in the Huaraz zone and one of the most sought after rental establishments for weekends events. Her husband, children and herself are responsible for preparing the food. With this S/800 soles loan, which will be paid back in 6 months, she will purchase 2% on plastic chairs for the restaurant "La Rinconada" that is located in Jr. Huaylas, a district of the city of Huaraz, becasue the ones she has are not enough.

Translated from Spanish by Bertolt Cantalice, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Plastic chairs purchase.

loans.name: Teresa

texts.es:
La señora Teresa  tiene 74 años , nació en Piscopampa caserío de Mache provincia de Otuzco del  departamento de La Libertad Perú,  cursó el primer año de primaria que en su tiempo se llamaba transición, no continuó estudiando más porque murió su madre cuando aun era muy pequeña y   a su padre no le interesaba que las hijas mujeres tengan instrucción.
Se casó a la edad de 18 años  y tiene 7 hijos, de los cuales una hija vive con ella y se ayudan mutuamente la señora Teresa tiene 20 nietos a quienes con su ejemplo les enseña a ser optimistas y a tenerle mucho amor al trabajo.
Anteriormente ella fue costurera, pero ahora se dedica a la compra y venta de material de reciclaje, por ejemplo: plásticos, objetos de fierro, cobre y aluminio, también baterías en desuso.
Recuerda con mucha alegría que el primer préstamo que le brindó  Manuela Ramos fue de 300 soles, hace ya 6 años, lo devolvió en 4 meses, con ese dinero compro cuyes y gallinas y los vendió a los restaurantes de Mache, con las ganancia compró material de reciclaje y así dio inicio a un negocio que actualmente le rinde mayores ganancias. Lo más importante para ella es que cuenta con muy buenos ahorros, manifiesta.
Con este préstamo de S/. 2,000  soles, el cual cancelará en 4 cuotas, piensa comprar baterías y otros materiales de reciclaje por los que le puedan pagar un poco más que por el plástico.
Actualmente sueña con seguir trabajando para seguir respondiendo por ella misma, sin necesidad de depender de nadie.
 Pertenece al Banco Comunal Mujeres de Trabajo del distrito de Mache.
texts.en:
Teresa is 74 years old and was born in Piscopampa, Peru. She completed the first year of primary school. She did not continue studying because her mother died when she was very young, and it was not important to her father that female children received an education. She married when she was eighteen, and has seven children. One daughter lives with her, and they help each other. Teresa has twenty grandchildren whom she teaches by example to be optimistic and be hard-working. Teresa used to be was a seamstress, but now she works in the buying and selling of recyclable material such as plastic, iron, copper, aluminum and used batteries. She remembers fondly the first loan of 100 USD that she received from Manuela Ramos six years ago. She returned it within four months, and with this money she bought guinea pigs and hens which she sold to restaurants. With her profits, she purchased recyclable materials and thus started a business which now yields greater profits. The most important thing to her is that she can count on her savings. With this loan of 675 USD, which she will pay off in four installments, she plans to buy batteries and other recyclable materials which are worth more than plastic. Now she dreams of continuing working so that she can answer only to herself, without depending on anyone. She is a member of the Working Women’s Communal Bank in the Mache district.

Translated from Spanish by PULP Translators, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of batteries, plastics, and other recycled materials.

loans.name: Semeni

texts.en:
Semeni H. M. is 32 years old and married with five children, ages three, four, nine, ten, and fourteen. Semeni has been selling spices in Zanzibar since 2007. She works every day from 8:00 am to 9:00 pm and earns a profit of approximately $15 each month.

She is now hoping to take out her first loan so that she may expand her business and increase her profit. She will use the loan to buy more spices for her shop.

loans.use: To buy more spices for her shop.

loans.name: Fati

texts.fr:
Madame O. Fati est une revendeuse de pagne et de bijoux dans le quartier Agoè. Elle est née en 1962 et s’est mariée à un transitaire qui travaille au port autonome de Lomé. Elle a trois (3) enfants qui fréquentent. Elle aide beaucoup son mari dans les dépenses de la famille. 
Elle est une cliente fidèle de WAGES et a bien remboursé les deux précédents crédits qu’elle a obtenus.
Ce troisième crédit qu’elle sollicite lui permettra de d’acheter 30 pièces de pagnes et 40 complets de bijoux afin de pouvoir bien servir ses clients au cours de ces périodes de fête.
texts.en:
Ms. Fati O. is a retailer of pagnes (coloful West African cloth) and jewelry in the Agoè district. She was born in 1962 and is married to a shipping agent who works at the autonomous port of Lomé. Fati has three children who attend school. She assists her husband a lot with covering family expenses.

She is a loyal client of WAGES and has repaid the two preceding loans that she had obtained. This third loan she is requesting will enable her to buy 30 lengths of pagnes cloth and 40 sets of jewelry in order to serve her customers well during this holiday period.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Commerce in pagnes and jewelry
